metadata.title: RETRACTED: Chinese medical staff request international medical assistance in fighting against COVID-19
metadata.author: Yingchun Zeng, Yan Zhen

introduction: E Province, China. The daily work we are doing is mainly focused on pro­vision of oxygen, electrocardio­ gram (ECG) monitoring, tube care,
T airway management, ventilator debugging, central venous intubation, haemodialysis care, and basic nursing care such as disposal and disinfection.

Chinese medical staff: Some nurses have fainted due to request international medical assistance in hypoglycaemia and hypoxia. In addition to the physical exhaustion, we are also suffering fighting against psychologically. While we are
D in their fight against the COVID-19 infection. We entered the Wuhan isolation ward as the first batch of medical aid workers from Guangdong
E Province, China. The daily work we are doing is mainly focused on pro­vision of oxygen, electrocardio­ gram (ECG) monitoring, tube care,
T airway management, ventilator debugging, central venous intubation, haemodialysis care, and basic nursing care such as disposal and disinfection.
C The conditions and environment here in Wuhan are more difficult and extreme than we could ever have imagined. There is a severe shortage of protective equipment,
A such as N95 respirators, face shields, goggles, gowns, and gloves. The goggles are made of plastic that must be repeatedly cleaned and
R sterilised in the ward, making them difficult to see through. Due to the need for frequent hand washing,
T several of our colleagues’ hands are covered in painful rashes. As a result of wearing an N95 respirator for extended periods of time and layers
E of protective equipment, some nurses now have pressure ulcers on their ears and forehead. When wearing a mask to speak with patients, our

R voices are muted, so we have to speak professional nurses, we are also human. Like everyone else, we feel helplessness, anxiety, and fear. Experienced nurses occasionally find the time to comfort colleagues and try to relieve our anxiety. But even experienced nurses may also cry, possibly because we do not know how long we need to stay here and we are the highest-risk group for COVID-19 infection. So far 1716 Chinese staff have been infected with COVID-19 and nine of them have unfortunately passed away. Due to an extreme shortage of health-care professionals in Wuhan, 14 000 nurses from across China have voluntarily come to Wuhan to support local medical health-care professionals. But we need much more help. We are asking nurses and medical staff from countries around the world to come to China now, to help us in this battle.
We hope the COVID-19 epidemic will end soon, and that people worldwide will remain in good health.

Department of Nursing, Third Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical Hospital, Guangzhou 510150, China (YiZ); Department of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Sun Yet-sen Memorial Hospital, Sun Yet-sen University, Guangzhou, China (YaZ).

Published Online February 24, 2020 https://doi.org/10.1016/ S2214-109X(20)30065-6 very loudly. Wearing four layers of gloves is abnormally clumsy and does not work—we can’t even open the packaging bags for medical devices, so giving patients injections is a huge challenge. In order to save energy and the time it takes to put on and take off protective clothing, we avoid eating and drinking for 2 hours before entering the isolation ward. Often, nurses’ mouths are covered in blisters.

On Jan 24, 2020, the authors came to Wuhan, China, to support the local nurses
D in their fight against the COVID-19 infection.
The authors entered the Wuhan isolation ward as the first batch of medical aid workers from Guangdong
Results: C The conditions and environment here in Wuhan are more difficult and extreme than the authors could ever have imagined.
There is a severe shortage of protective equipment, A such as N95 respirators, face shields, goggles, gowns, and gloves.
R sterilised in the ward, making them difficult to see through.

Experienced nurses occasionally find the time to comfort colleagues and try to relieve the anxiety.
Even experienced nurses may cry, possibly because the authors do not know how long the authors need to stay here and the authors are the highest-risk group for COVID-19 infection.
1716 Chinese staff have been infected with COVID-19 and nine of them have passed away.
Due to an extreme shortage of health-care professionals in Wuhan, 14 000 nurses from across China have voluntarily come to Wuhan to support local medical health-care professionals.
The authors need much more help.
The authors are asking nurses and medical staff from countries around the world to come to China to help them in this battle.
